A self-configurable large-scale virtual manufacturing environment for collaborative designers
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Manufacturing and Construction
  • Published: 08 January 2010

A self-configurable large-scale virtual manufacturing environment for collaborative designers

  • Hyunsoo Lee1 &
  • Amarnath Banerjee1 

Virtual Reality volume 15, pages21–40(2011)Cite this article

  • 314 Accesses

  • 10 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

As manufacturing environments are getting distributed and increasing in size, the related virtual environments are getting larger and more closely networked together. This trend has led to a new paradigm—large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME). It supports networked and distributed virtual manufacturing to meet manufacturing system requirements. Since it contains a large number of virtual components, an effective data structure and collaborative construction methodology are needed. A metaearth architecture is proposed as the data structure for representing LSVME. This architecture consists of virtual space layer, mapping layer, library layer and ontology layers, which describe interaction among virtual components and has the ability to analyze the characteristics of virtual environment. In addition, it increases reusability of virtual components and supports self-reconfiguration for manufacturing simulation. A heuristic construction method based on graph theory is proposed using this architecture. It prevents redundant design of virtual components and contributes to an effective construction scheduling technique for collaborative designers.

Introduction

Many forms of virtual reality (VR) technologies have been extensively applied in manufacturing systems to improve design, modeling, visualization and analysis of these systems. One of the popular application areas is in computer-aided design/manufacturing (CAD/CAM) domains. In the CAD domain, 2D drawing-based design methods have evolved into 3D-based design methods such as CSG, B-rep, voxel and so on. It has been effectively combined with immersive technologies including haptics. Instead of designing 3D products using keyboard and mouse, designers can create 3D objects by shaping and touching using haptic devices (Stone 2001; Chu et al. 1998). These trends originated from mechanical CAD domain and have extended into many other CAD domains including architecture CADs, textile CADs and so on. The functionality combining CAD design with VR technologies has been extended from design and modification stages into evaluation and feedback stages. In CAM domain, VR technologies have been used for visualization of simulation output model and monitoring of manufacturing processes. Different types of machining equipment such as milling machines, lathes and drilling machine are represented in a virtual environment and their cutting operations/processes are simulated and monitored (Seo et al. 2006). These approaches are linked with other manufacturing components including conveyor belts and industrial robots, so that a complete factory-level simulation and monitoring can be fulfilled in a virtual environment. Nowadays, these approaches are extended to computer integrated manufacturing (CIM) system level activities such as task planning and scheduling (Chung and Peng 2007). These applications mainly demonstrate how manufacturing elements are represented using virtual reality technologies in a virtual environment, their interactions and effective simulation. This concept has been applied in a few commercial simulation tools such as DELMIA (IGRIP series), Automod and several other systems.

Another major application area in virtual manufacturing environments is the large-scale networked and collaborative area, which supports broader manufacturing concepts such as collaborative manufacturing environment or networked manufacturing environment. While the previous domain focused on one or some manufacturing elements, this approach handles a lot of manufacturing elements which are linked with each other using interaction concept and supports remote control and its processing. Even though this area is still immature and is an emerging concept from the point of view of virtual manufacturing concept, its necessities and importance continue to grow.

As the size of manufacturing systems is getting larger and the locations of manufacturing resources are getting more distributed, a new paradigm supporting distributed/networked/large-scale virtual manufacturing environments is needed. Table 1 describes general manufacturing architectures and related virtual manufacturing environments from the viewpoint of control levels. In Table 1, the classification of “inner facility domain” follows Gardner’s terms: equipment—work station—cell—shop—facility level (Gardner 1985).

Currently, many commercial virtual manufacturing systems and environments support mainly inner facility domain. The virtual manufacturing environment beyond “inner facility” domain has been studied to a limited extent. The focus of this paper is on a large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME)—which falls in the “facility to facility” domain and “facilities to other domains”. LSVME can be used for a multi-distributed control of manufacturing devices, a simulation of manufacturing environment in a metaverse-scale environment and central monitoring/tracking of several remote facilities. Since it is large-scale virtual environment, the critical need is of an efficient data structure, which can describe targeted large-scale manufacturing environments. Even though many large-scaled virtual environments have suggested their own data structure, they do not reflect the characteristics of manufacturing environments and do not explain their construction algorithms for general use. In this paper, we suggest an efficient large-scale virtual manufacturing environment architecture and demonstrate how it can be effectively constructed by collaborative designers.

Section 2 explains the background of LSVME and reviews related literature. In Sect. 3 and 4, a new efficient data structure for LSVME is proposed, and its dynamic organization is explained. Sect. 5 describes an effective construction method of LSVME and a case study is provided in Sect. 6.

Background and literature review

As mentioned in the previous section, this paper proposes a large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME). A large-scale virtual manufacturing environment shares the characteristics of large-scale virtual environment (LSVE) and virtual manufacturing environment (VME). Table 2 describes the characteristics of two virtual environments: LSVE and VME.

Many researchers have studied large-scale virtual environments (LSVEs) for general purpose applications. In the domain of LSVE, many terms such as metaverse (Stepenson 1993; Jaynes et al. 2003), networked virtual environments (NVEs) (Lamotte et al. 2008), massively multi-user virtual environment (MMVE) (Hariri et al. 2008; Keller and Simon 2003) and large-scale distributed simulations (LSDSs) (Morse et al. 2000) have been proposed along with their architectures. The term metaverse originates from Stephenson’s novel: Snow Crash, which is a synthetic word for meta and universe. The prefix meta means “beyond” and universe means “our real environment”. In essence, metaverse indicates “beyond our real environment” which means a fully immersive 3D virtual space beyond internet. In a metaverse, each person has his/her virtual feature (avatar) and interacts with other people and virtual components for various activities including ordinary life as well as economic activities/transactions. Frey et al. (2008) modified the original concept of metaverse and defined it to a real time simulation environment. In their definition, the term-verse signifies virtual earth real time simulation environment. In a LSVE including metaverse, the most important factor is how the interactivities among avatars and virtual objects can be represented and constructed. Many LSVE architectures have an interest management (IM) module as a key component for describing various interactions. Most IM modules’ roles are to determine interest area (IA) or area of interest (AOI). IA/AOI can be mainly classified into Delaunay-based region or range-based region as shown in Fig. 1. Figure 1 describes these IA/AOI in a large-scale virtual environment.

Delaunay-based interest region is based on the interactive relationships in a physical environment. In a physical environment, each component has interaction relationships with other components. These relationships are kept and expanded in the virtual environment. On the other hand, range-based interest region (Fig. 1b) is based on some predefined fixed ranges, which each virtual component may have. This range can be a grid/circle/sphere or Voronoi shape. As each component has an interaction range, a virtual component is usually centered on each divided interest region. If an avatar or moving object gets in that region, the virtual component in that region is activated and interacts with getting-in avatars.

Most of LSVE researchers put great emphasis on this interaction among virtual components and its architecture. However, they do not consider construction aspects such as reusability of common components and how they can be constructed effectively. These issues are related to the data structure and modeling of LSVE. In terms of data model, research studies in data model of LSVE are very limited when compared to interaction management. Gunadi et al. (2002) suggest a method for constructing LSVE from multi-view images. These images include airborne laser profiler and images taken using 3D laser scanner and digital cameras. In their approach, detailed views are segmented using a region-based method and range data is modeled using polygonization. Since the basic unit of their constructed LSVE is a polygon, the model size is proportional to the size of the real model. The main limitation of this kind of data model is the difficulty in identifying relationships among polygons. For example, classifications between polygons from building #A and from building #B could be unresolved or might need human intervention. This problem becomes larger in virtual environments with many interactions among components such as virtual manufacturing models. Wang and Hua (2006) have reviewed research studies involving LSVE modeling. The reviews of various 3D city models and systems show that there are three types of LSVE modeling techniques: geometry-based techniques, image-based techniques and image hybrid techniques (Shan et al. 2002). Geometry-based techniques are based on reconstruction techniques from point clouds. These point clouds are usually acquired from 3D scanners. Image-based techniques use computer vision techniques using multi-view 2D images. However, this review of LSVE modeling techniques overlooks the data structure issues of reconstructed LSVEs. In general, data structures of various LSVEs use B-rep representation. Many LSVE models for city modeling are represented by surfaces (Ulm 2002; Gruen and Wang 2003), planes (Haala and Anders 1997; Vosselman and Dijkman 2001; Vosselman 2002), polyhedral outlines (Rottensteiner 2003) or polygons (Gunadi et al. 2002; Shan et al. 2002). These data models and structures encounter substantial limitations as the size of LSVE grows larger and with increasing interactions between components.

Another limitation of current LSVEs is that they are targeted to social or economic domains. It means that they seldom consider the characteristics and dynamics in a manufacturing domain. Table 3 shows some of the existing large-scale virtual environments (LSVEs) with consideration to construction aspect and manufacturing aspect.

While a LSVE’s architecture concentrates on interest management in a virtual environment, a virtual manufacturing environment (VME) considers the hierarchy/architecture of virtual manufacturing components and simulation functionality as the most important factors. In addition, the interest management of LSVE can be similarly compared to the simulation function or behavior architecture (Banerjee et al. 2000). Chawla and Banerjee (2001) proposed the modified scene graph structure to represent the hierarchy of manufacturing components. The architecture for the simulation of virtual manufacturing components is provided through updating of the parent–child relationships. Banerjee et al. (2000) proposed a behavioral layer architecture using virtual manufacturing lattice (VML) and virtual manufacturing script (VMS). Even though these methods suggested an effective virtual manufacturing architecture for simulation/behavior functions using modified scene graph, a construction algorithm considering reusability and the architecture for large-scale virtual model was not provided. Since 2001, research studies in VMS have concentrated on two directions. These directions are applications in manufacturing domain using virtual reality (VR) technologies and convergence between VMS and information technology (IT). The first trend has evolved since the early stage of VMS. These kinds of research studies include applications of virtual prototyping and manufacturing simulation using virtual simulation. The other trend in VMS is the convergence of IT and VMS. Offodile and Abdel-Malek (2002) have suggested a new virtual manufacturing paradigm through convergence between IT technologies and manufacturing strategies. This trend is found in Chan et al. (2006) as well. Their approaches have focused on an IT-based virtual manufacturing protocol. However, their platforms remain as conceptual models. There are very few research studies from the point of view of modeling of VMS. Park (2005) suggests a construction method of virtual-flexible manufacturing system (FMS). His approach is based on functional analysis and its protocol of components in FMS. Using a similar approach, Xiaofeng et al. (2008) and Goh and Zhang (2003) have analyzed the manufacturing protocols for modeling VMS. However, these approaches are used for modeling comparatively small-size virtual manufacturing systems such as VMS with the size at a workstation level. In addition, these modeling approaches fail to describe detailed interactions among virtual manufacturing components.

To support large-scale virtual manufacturing environment and overcome the limitations of current LSVEs/VMEs, a new virtual manufacturing architecture (metaearth architecture) is provided here with an emphasis towards effective construction of large-scale virtual environments. The construction algorithm using metaearth architecture is explained for collaborative construction.

The architecture for large-scale virtual manufacturing environment

The metaearth architecture

As discussed in the previous section, LSVE architectures are mainly based on interactions among virtual components. This interaction can be captured using a graph structure: interaction graph. In an interaction graph, a vertex signifies a virtual component and an edge indicates the interaction between the vertices (virtual components). If the LSVE’s architecture uses range-based interest module, this graph’s vertices may have additional ranges as an interest area. This interaction graph supports representations of interactions and covers the limitation of scene graphs. Even though the scene graph concept is one of the most effective tools for representing virtual manufacturing environments, it has serious problems in scalability and complexity. When there exists many virtual objects and their complicated hierarchy, a scene graph’s effectiveness decreases significantly. In addition, a scene graph cannot represent the interaction among virtual components. Table 4 describes the characteristics of these graphs and their limitations.

To overcome these limitations and represent large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME) architecture, the metaearth architecture is proposed here. The term “metaearth” is a synthetic word comprising of meta and earth. This architecture is derived from the earth’s structure that consists of two core layers (outer core and inner core layers), mantle layer and crust layer. In the metaearth architecture, the crust layer corresponds to virtual space layer where the virtual manufacturing components exist. The core layers correspond to the library layer and ontology layer. These layers are in charge of the assets of virtual components in the virtual space layer. The mantle layer corresponds to a mapping layer that describes the mapping from shared components in the library layer to virtual manufacturing components in the virtual space layer. Table 5 and Fig. 2 describe each layer’s role and components.

Operators/users communicate with virtual components in the virtual space (crust) layer in the metaearth architecture. The virtual space layer consists of multi-interaction graph as shown in the bottom portion of Fig. 3. This graph’s vertices represent virtual components. These components are replicated components from library (outer core) layer’s components. The library layer’s role is similar to the library/asset of virtual components used in virtual space layer. Each virtual component in the virtual space layer has the interactive relationship(s) with other virtual components. Figure 3 illustrates the interaction among some virtual manufacturing components.

In Fig. 3a, the industrial robot loads products from one conveyor belt to the other conveyor belt. It can be interpreted as the industrial robot communicating/interacting with the two conveyor belts. This relationship is represented using interaction graph shown below the snapshot in Fig. 3a. Figure 3b provides the interaction graph for a small manufacturing cell. In Fig. 3b, conveyor belt #1 and #2 can be modeled using one conveyor belt model. The original model of the conveyor belt is defined in the library layer. It is replicated into two conveyor belts in the virtual space layer. This approach increases the reusability of virtual models. Figure 4 shows this mapping and replication process. In Fig. 4, the information in the mapping layer contains the rotation axes and angles, center positions’ coordinates and scale vector. This description is represented using XML format for distributed configuration between multi-virtual space layer and library layer.

The metaearth architecture is useful from the perspective of high reusability of virtual components and helps checking the structure of virtual environment. This architecture represents interaction relation in virtual space layer and has ontology information in ontology layer. The mapping between virtual space layer and library/ontology layer is done in the mapping (mantle) layer using XML format.

This architecture can be expanded to many large-scale distributed/networked manufacturing environments (Hu et al. 2006). In this case, the virtual space layer can be divided into multi-interaction graphs. The library layers as a virtual models’ library can be divided into more detail levels and sublayers. Each mapping is done by checking the ontology.

Figure 5 shows eight characteristics of the metaearth architecture: reusability, support of large-scale virtual environment, scalability, collaboration, distributed control, dynamic reconfiguration, interaction management and supporting manufacturing aspect.

Construction of the metaearth architecture form real world

This section describes how the proposed metaearth architecture can be modeled from real world. This procedure consists of five steps. Table 6 describes the five steps for constructing metaearth architecture from real world. To describe this procedure clearly, a virtual representation of a small manufacturing system (TAMCAM laboratory) using the metaearth architecture is provided. The TAMCAM laboratory (http://ise.tamu.edu/varl/html/facility.htm) is a manufacturing systems laboratory housed in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering at Texas A&M University.

Figure 6 shows the snapshot images of TAMCAM laboratory and identified virtual components. After identifying all components, which will be represented in the virtual environment, designers create interaction graph considering manufacturing interaction. This interaction graph generates a virtual space layer in the metaearth architecture for targeted manufacturing system. Figure 7 illustrates step 2.

In the virtual space layers, the same component and similar components are classified. Through this process, the common components are extracted, and these can be used for virtual model library/assets. Even though one virtual component is not shared with any other virtual component, it will be used as a reference model in the next LSVME. Figure 8 illustrates step 3—the generation of library layer. In Fig. 8b, 27 virtual manufacturing components (in virtual space layer) are reduced to 13 shared virtual components (in library layer). It means that the designer of virtual TAMCAM laboratory can construct the virtual manufacturing environment using these 13 virtual components only. After extracting virtual components in the library layer, these can be grouped with respect to manufacturing ontology: computer and controller, material processor (MP), material handler (MH), material transporter (MT), human and furniture. Figure 9 shows the ontology grouping in the library layer.

At the end of step 4, the virtual space layer and library/ontology layer are produced. The mapping layer from library/ontology layer from virtual space layer is generated connecting the virtual components at the ontology layer with the instantiated components at the virtual space layer. The final metaearth architecture is shown in Fig. 10.

Using this metaearth architecture, it can be seen that the virtual TAMCAM laboratory consists of 27 virtual objects, and these objects are constructed using 13 common virtual components that are present in the library layer. In addition, the characteristics of this laboratory can be understood using ontology. This information can be used for self-reconfiguration of the virtual space layer. This is explained in Sect. 4.

This metaearth architecture can be expanded into a significantly bigger large-scale virtual environment. In the previous example, a node/vertex in virtual space layer represents one manufacturing component such as conveyor belt, robot or machining equipment. Instead of this, a node/vertex can be used to represent a factory or plant. Figure 11 illustrates the distributed virtual plants concept. Using the metaearth architecture, the distributed facilities can be established effectively with the shared components.

To show that the metaearth architecture supports 3D distributed virtual environments, 50 arbitrary 3D points are randomly generated as the locations of 50 plants (Fig. 11a). The interaction graph is generated as shown in Fig. 11b. These interactions among 50 plants are randomly generated. Eight plants are considered as shared virtual objects in the library layer. Based on this situation, the library layer and mapping layer are created as shown in Fig. 11c, d. Finally, Fig. 12 shows the multi-distributed virtual plant model using the metaverse architecture. In Fig. 12, some of the interactions are removed for a clearer understanding.

Self-reconfiguration of metaearth architecture

This section describes the self-reconfiguration property of the metaearth architecture. Since the metaearth architecture is the data structure of a large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME), some of the manufacturing characteristics should be considered. Among manufacturing characteristics, simulation and dynamic reconfiguration of manufacturing processes are essentially needed in a virtual manufacturing domain. Even though existing virtual manufacturing tools such as IGRIP and Automod support simulation and monitoring function using virtual models, they have some limitations. Reconfiguration of manufacturing processes can occur due to a number of factors, such as breakage of manufacturing resources, change of product order/scheduling and so on. In such situations, the reconfiguration is executed manually by manufacturing process designers. The configuration change of pre-constructed virtual environments may consume significant amount of time and labor. Due to these reasons, dynamic reconfiguration ability is considered as a crucial factor in the deployment of a large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME). The metaearth architecture supports the self-reconfiguration ability using ontology and mapping layers. Figure 13 shows an existing virtual manufacturing system/environment’s case from the point of view of reconfiguration.

In Fig. 13, the original process consists of two parallel processes. One process consists of conveyor belt #1, robot #1 and lathe #1. Parts arrive and flow through conveyor belt #1. Robot #1 picks up parts and unloads to lathe #1. The other process consists of conveyor belt #2, robot #2 and milling machine #1. Similarly, robot #2 picks up parts from conveyor belt #2 and unloads on milling machine #1. According to a simulation scenario, suppose that robot #1 breaks down and stops functioning. In this case, two alternative solutions can be considered. The first solution is to repair robot #1. Some stochastic information using mean time to failure (MTTF) and mean time to repair (MTTR) of robot can be used to simulate this situation. This solution does not need reconfiguration of the existing virtual manufacturing environment. However, the other solution needs the reconfiguration of current virtual manufacturing environment. In the second alternative solution, robot #2 can be used for the first parallel process. To do this, the six components’ locations and orientation have to be changed. This reconfiguration can be done manually. If this configuration requires more time, operator and analyzers may run simulation with the first alternative solution. This situation decreases the effectiveness of virtual manufacturing environment.

In the metaearth architecture, this reconfiguration can be executed automatically and dynamically as the architecture supports large-scale virtual manufacturing environment and uses mapping/ontology layers. Since the metaearth architecture handles LSVME, it has many subvirtual space layers. These can be used as reference models for reconfiguration. Figures 14, 15 and 16 provide the conceptual model of self-reconfiguration using the metaearth architecture.

The original metaearth architecture is shown in Fig. 14. The original architecture contains many subvirtual spaces. These subvirtual spaces can be divided with respect to regional distances or a pre-defined grid. In this metaearth architecture, suppose that robot #1 breaks down and stops functioning. In this situation, subvirtual space excluding robot #1 is analyzed with respect to used components (library layer) and ontology (ontology layer). As a result of the analysis, the ontology information such as the types/number of virtual manufacturing ontology (2 MT, 1 MH, 2 MP) are extracted. With this information, similar virtual spaces are searched and the closest virtual space is selected. Based on the mapping layers, and information from the searched subvirtual space, the target virtual space’s mapping layer is modified and relocated dynamically. Figure 15 illustrates this process. After a self-reconfiguration, the final metaearth model is shown in Fig. 16.

The self-reconfiguration ability is based on many reference models from large-scaled virtual environment and the metaearth architecture’s mapping, library and ontology layers. The self-reconfiguration property of the metaearth architecture is a significant advantage that can be effectively used for many virtual manufacturing simulations.

Collaborative construction of large-scale virtual manufacturing environment

This section describes how a large-scale virtual manufacturing environment (LSVME) can be constructed by collaborative designers using the metaearth architecture. As mentioned in the previous sections, the metaearth architecture has four layers for effective construction and capturing manufacturing ontology/structure. These layers have interaction relationship, share virtual components/ontology information and have mapping relations. After creating the metaverse architecture, one of the remaining problems is the construction sequence of virtual components. This issue is very crucial in the construction of large-scale virtual environments. Since virtual environment has many interactions and complicated structure, the construction order has an influence on the relative location and structure of other virtual components. Also, the construction order is closely tied with the simulation of manufacturing facilities. For general purpose applications, the construction order is determined with respect to the size/complexity of virtual objects. If the objective of a virtual environment is to construct a virtual building or a virtual city, this approach may be beneficial. However, if the objective of a virtual environment is to develop a manufacturing application, simulation and interaction should be considered to determine the construction order. In the metaearth architecture, these considerations can be achieved with the graph theory concepts of dominating set, vertex cover and minimal spanning tree. Dominating set is the subset D of vertices such that every vertex, which is not in D, is adjacent to a vertex in D (Diestel 2005). Vertex cover is the subset VC of vertices such that every edge has at least one endpoint in VC (Diestel 2005). A minimal spanning tree is a subgraph MST that is a tree and spans all vertices with minimum size of edges (Diestel 2005).

Figure 17 illustrates the interaction graph, dominating set, vertex cover and minimal spanning tree. In Fig. 17d, the minimal spanning tree is acquired from a connected graph. It means that the original interaction graph’s (Fig. 17a) unconnected vertices are eliminated through preprocessing. In the metaverse architecture, the consideration of construction order is influenced by manufacturing simulation. The simulation is fulfilled using interaction in the metaearth architecture. It means that if a vertex has many interaction edges in the interaction graph (virtual space), this vertex interacts many components and likely to perform more complicated operations in the simulation. However, the metaverse architecture can have many vertices with the same number of interaction edges. So, the dominating set and vertex cover concept can be used instead of considering the number of interaction edges.

According to the definitions, the dominating set D covers all vertices using adjacency, and the vertex cover VC covers all interaction edges using adjacency. So, if D and VC are constructed earlier, the backbone of virtual space is constructed and only the adjacent vertices remain. Among D and VC, D is constructed earlier due to the coverage ability of all vertices. Using this method, the initial sequence is generated.

After acquiring the initial construction sequence, shared components in the library layer are considered. The construction means that the designer constructs virtual components in the library layer. When a designer considers D, VC and MST and attempts to construct virtual components, s/he needs to check the library layer. If it already exists in the library layer, the designer only replicates it using mapping layers into the virtual space layer. If it does not exist in the library layer, the designer constructs it in the library layer. The initial construction sequence can be significantly decreased by checking the library layers. If there are multiple collaborative designers, the assignment rule follows the Johnson’s rule (Chen and Chen 2009). The earliest finishing designer constructs the next waiting virtual object in the construction order. Figure 18 describes the sequencing procedure that is used to generate the construction order.

From the metaearth architecture, the dominating set D and vertex cover VC are extracted. Based on these vertices, the first sequence is generated with the order of D–VC–remaining vertices. The final sequence is generated using this sequence and the library layer. The final sequence is the reduced sequence and redundant-free construction sequence. Figure 18b illustrates the assignment of two designers using Johnson’s rule.

This algorithm is applied to the distributed virtual plant, which is described in Sect. 3.2. Figure 19 shows the D, VC and MST acquired from the interaction graph.

The initial construction sequence is generated using the extracted D, VC and MST. The initial construction sequence contains all vertices (virtual components) in the virtual space layer. The sequence may contain some redundant virtual components. These redundant components in the initial sequence are eliminated using sequence checking and the library layer containing common components. After considering the library layer, the final sequence is generated as shown in Fig. 20.

In view of algorithm complexity, this algorithm follows O(|V||E|). Since it is polynomial time complexity, this heuristic algorithm is considered as an effective collaborative construction methods. Table 7 shows the detail size and algorithm complexity.

Case study: modeling and collaborative construction of LSVME using the metaearth architecture

This section provides a case study using the metaearth architecture and graph-based heuristic construction algorithm described in Sects. 3 and 5, respectively. As an example, the Emerging Technology and Economic Development (ETED) building, which is under construction at Texas A&M University, is created as a virtual 3D model. Once completed, this six-story, 212,000 gross square feet building will house a couple of engineering departments, offices, classrooms, conference rooms and several laboratories, including the relocated TAMCAM laboratory mentioned earlier. Given the dimensions of the building, its virtual model can be considered as a large-size virtual environment (LSVE) with a manufacturing facility (TAMCAM) housed within it. Figure 21 shows some drawings of the ETED building.

According to all the architectural and construction drawings of the ETED building, it consists of more than 8,600 components. These include components for building structure (e.g. wall/floor/ceiling components), furniture (e.g. white board/desk/table/chair), laboratory equipment (e.g. robot/conveyor belt/machine/chemical devices), other devices (e.g. computer/monitor/copier/printer) and so on. Table 8 shows the detailed number of components for each floor.

It is obvious that an efficient data modeling structure and construction method is needed to model this building into a virtual environment. Since the total 8,665 components include many common components, the identification of common components is a crucial step for its successful modeling. Without this procedure and data model, the detailed modeling of LSVME for the building will be extremely cumbersome. In addition, a number of components in the laboratories and facilities will have interactions with one or more components. The representation of these interactions is one of the key descriptions of LSVME. Many virtual modeling techniques reviewed in Sect. 2 ignore this point. Most existing virtual modeling methods may create just the outer structures of the building or small portions of the building into virtual models without incorporating the level of interactions that are involved. As discussed in Sects. 3, 4 and 5, the metaearth architecture is an efficient framework for achieving successful modeling of large-scale environments and interactions between components. Figure 22 shows the procedure for generating LSVE of the ETED building.

For applying the metaearth architecture, the 8,665 components are extracted through analyzing drawings of the ETED building. These components are analyzed and grouped into common components. The initial metaearth model is generated based on this process. This metaearth model is streamlined through a more detailed analysis. This process constructs a well-formed library layer and ontology layer. The finalized metaearth structure is applied with the graph-based heuristics construction method for collaborative construction of LSVME. In this case study, 48 groups are identified in the library layer and 16 groups are classified in the ontology layer. Table 9 describes some example groups in library layer and ontology layer.

The well-classified library layer and ontology layer are mapped into the virtual space layer with the 8,665 components through the mapping layer. Interactions are represented in the virtual space layer.

After generation of the final well-formed metaearth architecture for the ETED building, the graph-based heuristics method described in Sect. 5 is applied for collaborative construction. In this example, 12 designers are participating in the modeling of a LSVME. Each designer designs and constructs more than 700 virtual objects locally prior to applying the metaearth architecture and the collaborative algorithm. In a real and traditional design scenario, these designers may be grouped and assigned to the modeling of each floor of the building with minimal amount of collaboration and coordination activities. There are potentially a large number of components that can be shared between the models of each floor if they are suitably organized and available. A traditional design situation often leads to the creation of duplicate models of the same or similar components mainly due to the nature and extent of available information for sharing designs. The collaborative construction algorithm using the metaearth architecture addresses this problem. Figure 23 shows the constructed virtual models in the 1st floor (a) and 2nd floor (b) of the ETED building.

In this figure, the dotted yellow rectangle represents chemical laboratories that share similar virtual components in the library layer. The solid red rectangles represent classrooms that share similar virtual components in library layer and ontology layer. This figure shows that the virtual components/models of a classroom or laboratory can be modified for modeling similar parts/sections. Table 10 shows the modeling result using the metaearth architecture and collaborative construction algorithm in this example.

This result shows that LSVME in this example can be generated by 75% less number of modeling components per designer (criteria: 12 designers) and 68% of total modeling time can be saved using the metaearth architecture and the collaborative construction algorithm. This type of comparison and results are likely to vary with every LSVME’s architecture and the degree of sharing components. However, the suggested approach is considered as an effective cooperative modeling approach for LSVME. Figure 24a shows the finished LSVME model, while Fig. 24b provides snapshots of one of its applications (navigation).

Conclusion and further studies

This paper handles the creation of large-scale virtual manufacturing environments (LSVMEs). Even though many research articles have studied large-scale virtual environments, they do not consider manufacturing aspects such as control, simulation and monitoring. In addition, existing virtual manufacturing environments usually consider inner-factory scale environment. As the manufacturing resources and locations are getting distributed and larger, there is a need for large-scale virtual networked/distributed manufacturing environments. The large-scale virtual manufacturing environments can be used for virtual supply chain network, control/monitoring of multi-distributed manufacturing sites and other distributed applications.

In this LSVME, the important factors are the representation of interaction among virtual components and construction methodologies. The suggested metaearth architecture is an effective data structure for representing LSVME. The metaearth architecture consists of 4 layers: virtual space layer, mapping layer, library layer and ontology layer. Virtual space layer is the communication layer between virtual components and operators. This layer is mapped to the library layer through a mapping layer. The existence of library layer prevents redundant design and increases reusability. The characteristics of the virtual environment can be easily analyzed using the ontology layer. One of the major advantages of using the metaearth architecture is the self-reconfiguration ability. The self-reconfiguration is achieved through other referenced subvirtual spaces and ontology layer. This functionality helps in the simulation of large-scale virtual manufacturing environments. The suggested metaearth architecture is considered as an effective data structure for large-scale virtual manufacturing environments from the point of view of reusability, self-reconfiguration, description of ontology, collaboration and helps in the reduction in redundant components during construction.

The construction sequence of a large-scale virtual manufacturing environment using the metaearth architecture is discussed in this paper. Using the suggested heuristic method, the redundant-free construction of large-scale virtual manufacturing environments can be achieved by a set of collaborative designers.

As further study, this architecture can be used for more general purpose applications such as social, economic or game-related large-scale virtual environments. Based on these objectives, the interaction graph in the virtual space layer and ontology layer’s grouping may change. The theoretical property of this architecture needs to be studied more. As this architecture is based on graph structure, related graph theory knowledge and properties can be used to make the architecture more efficient. As the suggested construction problem is based on a NP-hard problem, a local search-based more effective heuristic algorithm should be considered.
